Award.AwardTitle: University of Puerto Rico-Mayaguez Early Career Faculty Research Enhancement

Division.LongName: Div Of Engineering Education and Centers

Award.AbstractNarration: This award to the University of Puerto Rico, Mayaguez will enable early career faculty to travel to Arlington to meet with program directors at the National Science Foundation and other agencies. The intellectual merit of this project lies in its ability to enhance the research activities of early career faculty via meetings to discuss their research areas and specific funding opportunities. By speaking directly with program directors about their proposed research, faculty can engage in deep discussion about research areas and activities, receiving feedback that will help them submit successful proposals and produce more impactful outcomes. The broader impact of this award is in its ability to support a population that is historically under-represented in engineering. The faculty are of Hispanic heritage and have positions at institutions that are Hispanic serving. Supporting the faculty efforts to successfully compete for research funds and generate more effective outcomes will directly benefit the graduate and undergraduate student populations at their institutions.

POR.DRECONTENT:
The University of Puerto Rico at Mayagüez (UPRM), a Hispanic Serving and Land Grant Institution established in 1911, is part of the University of Puerto Rico (UPR) system. UPRM is the only Campus in this system that offers engineering degrees. The School of Engineering is the key contributor to Research, and Development activities in UPRM and represents the major nation-wide contributor of US Hispanic Engineers.

The UPRM School of Engineering fully supports its young faculty to become Nation-wide competitive. Although active mentoring, coaching, and general guidance practices are part of our efforts, there is no comparison with a face-to-face interaction with leaders of the sponsoring agencies.

Thanks to the granted NSF award, young faculty had the opportunity to meet NSF Program Managers, receive guidance about the focus areas, and learn about current and potential opportunities to support their research initiatives. This kind of project was of great benefit to UPRM young faculty since they had the opportunity to receive first-hand general guidance about the focus of their areas of research and explore possibilities of getting involved with NSF logistics, for instance, serving as panelists.

Accordingly, on April 8, 2015, a first delegation of sixteen young faculty of the UPRM School of Engineering, together with the Dean of the UPRM College of Engineering, Dr. Agustin Rullán, visited NSF headquarters to meet Dr. Pramod Khargonekar, Head Engineering Directorate, and program managers from different divisions. Four more faculties visited NSF on October 23 and 29 and November 18, 2015, making a total of twenty young professors who were impacted by this project. The short-term outcomes were far above the expectations; four of UPRM Engineering faculty (Yomaira Pagan, Chemical Engineering, Pedro Tarafa and Alessandra Morales, Civil Engineering and Surveying, and Guillermo Araya, Mechanical Engineering) were invited to serve as panelists for NSF (CBET Catalysis/Biocatalysis Biomass Conversion, Nano-Bio Phenomena and Processes in the Environment, and Fluid Dynamics, and Graduate Research Fellowship Program 2016, respectively).  Tarafa was also invited to participate in the AEESP workshop on education and research in environmental engineering at Yale University.  Pedro Resto, another young faculty from Mechanical Engineering received important feedback to focus his NSF CAREER Proposal (Development of Sensors for Water Quality) to be submitted to the Environmental Engineering Division. Also, Dr. Rafael Méndez, faculty at the Electrical and Computer Engineering Department, identified research opportunities about the economic aspects of energy for sustainability. Furthermore, the kind of close environment developed during and after this visit, contributed to establish a research team (Dr. Emmanuel Arzuaga, Electrical and Computer engineering, Drs. Sylvia Rodríguez, General Engineering, and Dr. Jonathan Muñoz, Civil Engineering and Surveying) to respond to future calls in the area of Geoscience Education.

 In short, the above described experience not only motivated but, specially, facilitated our young faculty learning about the research and networking opportunities within the National Science Foundation in benefit of the progress of their research paths.
